newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-WMC sees nickel demand growing 3 pct.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-WMC sees nickel demand growing 3 pct.

text.p: Australian resources group WMC Ltd said on Tuesday it expects global primary nickel demand to grow by around three percent, or 30,000 tonnes a year, over the next few years.
The forecast takes into account the impact of scrap or recycled, nickel on the market, Mark Cutifani, manager of nickel operations for WMC, told the Australian Nickel conference here.
"In particular, scrap has been an area that we found hard to pick and certainly has occupied a lot our time in discussion," Cutifani said.

"We see overall that demand for primary nickel in the next few years will certainly be around three percent and we used that in our base line projection on what we think the market wil do," Cutifani said.
From a supply side, western world production is at a record high, Cutifani said. But he said limited capacity existed in the marketplace, providing room for new projects.
"At the moment we see at least 240,000 tonnes of new capacity ready to come on stream," Cutifani said.
As a result, within five years, eight years worth of capacity is poised to come on stream, he said.
"This includes the giant Voisey's Bay nickel project in Labrador, Canada," Cutifani said.
"We see another 356,000 tonnes in projects that have muted or discussed in the marketplace," he said.
Cutifani said WMC expects the nickel price to range between US$3.00 and $3.50 a pound for now but at some point it is expected to go into decline.
Nickel currently fetches about US$3.14 a pound.
